text.value: Other condiments: coffee, tea including milk in tea
Other condiments: coffee, tea, milk in tea
Nervous system (shaking, paralysis, circling, behavior change)
Permanently unable to work (disabled, or non‑working elderly) or chronically ill (unable to work in the production seasons
Working elderly / partially disabled (able to do light work only)
Adult (able to do full adult workload)
Working child (herding livestock; domestic chores; childcare; may be hired or fostered out)
Skin problems [ e.g. Mange (, sheep scab (lophalo or sekwape), sheep/goat pox etc)
Non-relative (including employees who live in house)
Keep on share basis for others
Tick-borne disease (local name): [e.g. East coast fever, Anaplasmosis, Babesiosis etc.)
To save the product for other household members
To save the product for selling
Trading in livestock and livestock products (not own)
Pests or disease attack that led to storage losses of crops
Pests or diseases that affected almost all crops before harvest
Theft of production tools and equipment
Compensation of losses to the buyer/seller
Payment of fine to the government
Purchased Labour input for herding (3 months)
Own Labour input for herding (3 months)
Free grazing and supplementary feeding with crop residue
Mainly grazing with some stall feeding
Household head (or other knowledgeable member) is not present at the house
Respondent does not have the time
Free grazing and supplementary feeing with concentrates
I do not have confidence over the drugs for these shops
Because it is not available in the area
On the road to the market
Trading in agricultural products (excluding livestock!) (not own produce)
Forced loss of tenancy of land
Formal Salaried employee (e.g. civil servant, domestic work)
General frequent infections [e.g Respiratory/Pneumonia, Diarrhoea etc)
Nutrition diseases and complications: [e.g. Milk fever, )
To buy female sheep/goat for reproduction
Oilseed by-product (Sesame seed, cotton seed, linseed, noug etc cacks)
Routine management-related tocontrollable diseases: [e.g. local name (foot rot), Mastitis(local name), worms]
Joint decision of husband and wife
Mainly stall feeding with some grazing
Crop by products (sweet potato vines, cassava leaves etc)
Because it is not available in the area
Notifiable diseases: [e.g. local name (FMD), local name; (Lumpy skin), local name; local name Rabies. Etc.]
Provides access to market for crops
Provides access to inputs and services for dairy
Provides ways to save money and get credit
Provides access to inputs and services for crops
Sheep Milk, cheese, butter, whey (aguat in Amharic)
Goat Milk, cheese, butter, whey (aguat in Amharic)
Fresh or dried fish or shellfish
Cow milk and milk products cheese, yogurt, butter, whey(aguat in Amharic)
Fear of being unable to pay
Agro industrial byproducts (vegetable waste, brewer’s waste etc)
I do not have confidence over the service
Destock fearing the damage of drought

input.label: Instruction for Enumerators 1. Introduce yourself and objectives of the survey 2. Ask the respondent whether she/he is engaged in trading sheep/goat and if YES ask her/his willingness to spare about one hour with you.

We are from International Center for Agricultural Research in Dry Areas and International Livestock Research Institute. These two institutions are going to work on the development of sheep/goat value chain in your area with the purpose of improving the wellbeing of female and male smallholder households and other value chain actors including traders, input suppliers, processors, transporters and consumers through improved income and nutrition. We would like to know the current status of sheep and goat production, input supply, marketing, processing and consumption in order to be able to measure changes over time after our interventions. For this purpose, we are interviewing randomly selected households and firms who keep sheep/ goats or process or market them or provide other services. Your business firm is one of these randomly selected firms and we would like to talk to you. The interview will take about 1 hour. All the information we obtain will remain strictly confidential and your answers will never be shared with anyone other than our team.
May I start now?

select1.label: A. Did the household consent to the interview?

item.label: Respondent does not have the time
Household head (or other knowledgeable member) is not present at the house

input.label: A2. Household GPS Coordinates:

N2.14 At what stage do you select female breeding stock?

item.label: Tick-borne disease (local name): [e.g. East coast fever, Anaplasmosis, Babesiosis etc.)
Notifiable diseases: [e.g. local name (FMD), local name; (Lumpy skin), local name; local name Rabies. Etc.]
Routine management-related tocontrollable diseases: [e.g. local name (foot rot), Mastitis(local name), worms]
